text:
today on hot thai kitchen we 
are making panang curry paste

Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
I'm making an incredibly popular curry called

Panang curry and this is actually a two-part 
episode in this video I'm going to make the

Panang curry paste from scratch for those of you 
who are hardcore DIY people and then next week

I'll post the video of the actual making of the 
Panang curry so if you're not subscribed now is

a good time to do so so that you will be alerted 
when I post a video of the pan and curry alright

let's get started for the Panang curry paste a 
Panang curry paste is like a souped up red curry

okay we've got the basic 10 ingredients that 
went into the red curry paste which are three

tablespoons of chopped garlic 1/4 cup of chopped 
shallots three tablespoons of chopped lemongrass

one tablespoon of chopped galangal a teaspoon 
of chopped cilantro root and a teaspoon and a

half of kaffir lime zest a teaspoon of coarse 
sea salt 7 to 15 dried chillies which have been

seeded and rehydrated a teaspoon of shrimp paste 
quarter teaspoon of white peppercorns so those

are basic 10 in addition to this there are three 
more ingredients that make Panang curry a Panang

curry and those three are a cumin seeds toasted 
always toasted cumin seeds to really open up the

the flavor potential I like to call it we've 
got toasted coriander seeds okay always again

toast your coriander seeds first and toast them 
separately from the cumin seeds don't toast them

together because they're different sizes and they 
don't take the same amount of time so we've got

that and then finally we've got 2 tablespoons 
of peanuts roasted and ground now peanuts is

supposed to be in every curry paste now if you 
have a peanut allergy and you're wondering how

you survived that Penang Korea that restaurant 
um - the good news is most commercially made pase

actually don't put the peanuts in for probably for 
allergy reasons sometimes they put in mung beans

instead and it's up to the discretion of the 
restaurant to add it or to not but today we're

making it the traditional way so we're going 
to add peanuts into the curry paste itself now

I know I went through the ingredient list quite 
quickly and if you have you're not familiar with

any of these ingredients I would recommend that 
you watch my red curry paste video because in in

that video I go through all the details of each 
ingredient what it looks like and also I talked

a lot about the fundamentals of curry paste 
making in the red curry paste video as well

so it's a good one to watch if you are unfamiliar 
with making curry paste from scratch and the link

to that video will be at the end of this video and 
also in the description of this video all right so

now that we've got all of our ingredients all we 
have to do is start so the first thing we need

to do is to grind all your dry spices which 
are cumin seeds the coriander seeds and also

the white peppercorns and we want to grind them 
first and separately because it's a lot easier

to get it to be finely ground right separately 
while there's nothing else in it once you start

mixing it with the wet stuff it's kind of hard 
to get it you know finely ground then okay so

once that's ground up we want to just separate it 
out while we do other things okay so there's that

and then we then we actually start this whole 
process okay we're going to go in first with

the rehydrated chiles and some sea salt now I want 
to talk about the chiles just a little bit in my

red curry video I use these dried chilies here 
and these dried chilies are smaller and they're

spicier these ones are bigger it's what I'm using 
right now and they're also less spicy if you can

get a hold of this it's better choice a lot of 
people do a combination of the two so they get

a combination of color and spice I couldn't 
find the big ones last time so I only use the

little ones so if you have that available at the 
store it's good to get the big ones for this and

the sea salt and the sea salt will help give 
a little bit of a friction to get started okay

so after it's more or less a paste you want to 
go in with all your dry spices and this will

actually help absorb some of the liquid that's in 
there and it will add a little bit more friction

and make it a little easier to grind from now on 
and then you can go in with all the tough herbs

we're going to go in with the lemongrass 
and the galangal lemongrass galangal okay

and the finer you chop them to begin with the 
faster it goes during the pounding just the

tip and now we're going to go in with kaffir 
lime zest and cilantro roots and pound that

down whoo okay now we're going to go in with 
the soft stuff the shallots shallot shallots

and garlic and we're almost there oh my gosh 
okay I may start crying during this process I

should have brought my goggles okay so at 
some point you're gonna think why is this

not as fine as the stuff I get from the bag and 
the answer is they're not doing it by hand and

you are so homemade paste is always gonna look 
a little bit rougher and you can sit there and

make it as fine as you like but you know what 
I'm pretty happy with this so we're gonna go in

with our last two ingredients the peanuts and 
the shrimp paste and now we're just gonna mix

it there's not a whole lot of pounding to 
do and that is pretty much our curry paste

once it's mixed then it's you're ready to go 
and you're ready to use it in your curry in

your Panang curry so I will see you next week 
for the Panang curry and for the full written

recipe of this bit of this curry paste you can 
visit hot Thai Kitchen calm and don't forget to

subscribe if you enjoy the show and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
you
you
